title: SHM forces - 2 stacked blocks on spring - friction

content.question: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> is on a horizontal surface, and Block <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> is on top of Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. A horizontal spring of spring constant <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math> is attached to a wall at one end and to Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> at the other end. Blocks <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> have masses <math alttext="M sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></msub></math> and <math alttext="M sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></msub></math>, respectively. There is a coefficient of static friction <math alttext="mu sub s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>s</mi></msub></math> between the two blocks, while friction between Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and the surface is negligible. Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> is pushed to the left against the spring, compressing the spring, and then released from rest, resulting in simple harmonic motion of the blocks-spring system. (a)i. The dot in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> represents Block <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> immediately after Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> is released from rest. On the dot, draw and label the forces (not components) exerted on Block <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>. Each force must be represented by a distinct arrow starting on, and pointing away from, the dot.

The blocks’ masses are <math alttext="M sub A, equals 5.0 kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>5.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></math> and <math alttext="M sub B, equals 1.5 kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>1.5</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></math>, the coefficient of static friction between Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and Block <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> is <math alttext="mu sub s, equals 0.35" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mi>s</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.35</mn></math>, and the spring constant of the spring is <math alttext="k equals 120 newtons per meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>120</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>N/m</mtext></math>.ii. Block <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> is removed, and Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> is allowed to oscillate by itself on the spring. A third block, Block <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>, has a mass <math alttext="M sub C, equals 2 M sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>M</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></math> and is attached to an identical spring, as shown in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>. Like Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>, Block <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> moves with negligible friction on a horizontal surface. Block <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> is made to oscillate with the same amplitude as Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>.A group of students observing the two blocks are discussing energy. One of the students makes the following claim:“Because kinetic energy is proportional to mass, the maximum kinetic energy of Block <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> is greater than the maximum kinetic energy of Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>.”(b) Indicate whether the student’s claim is correct. Justify your answer.
